summary:
The Security Council,

Recalling previous resolutions and presidential statements,
Reaffirms strong commitment to Syria's sovereignty, independence, unity, and territorial integrity.

Appalled by escalating violence, over 150,000 deaths, including 10,000 children.

Grave alarm at humanitarian situation deterioration: 10 million in need, 6.4 million internally displaced, 4.5 million in hard-to-reach areas, 240,000 in besieged areas.

Deploring non-compliance with resolution 2139 (2014) and Presidential Statement of 2 October 2013.

Commends UN efforts, humanitarian and medical personnel.

Appreciates regional countries' efforts to accommodate 2.8 million refugees.

Condemns widespread human rights and international humanitarian law violations.

Stresses need to end impunity, bring perpetrators to justice.

Expresses alarm at indiscriminate attacks, aerial bombings, barrel bombs, artillery, shelling, air strikes, torture, and grave violations against children.

Demands parties demilitarize medical facilities, schools, and civilian facilities.

Reaffirms Syrian authorities' primary responsibility to protect population.

Recalling need for respect of international humanitarian law.

Expresses alarm at extremism, targeting of civilians, terrorism.

Disturbed by withholding of consent to relief operations, impeding humanitarian supplies.
Emphasizing the worsening humanitarian situation in Syria without a political solution, the Security Council reiterates its support for the Geneva Communiqué of 30 June 2012. 
The Council demands all parties work towards the immediate and comprehensive implementation of the Geneva Communiqué to end violence and facilitate a Syrian-led process. 
Recalling its intent to take further steps in case of non-compliance with resolution 2139 (2014), 
The Council determines the deteriorating humanitarian situation in Syria constitutes a threat to peace and security in the region. 
It underscores Member States' obligation under Article 25 of the Charter to accept and carry out the Council's decisions. 
The Council reiterates all parties, particularly Syrian authorities, must comply with international humanitarian law and human rights law, and fully implement resolution 2139 (2014) and its Presidential Statement of 2 October 2013. 
It authorizes UN humanitarian agencies to use specific border crossings and conflict lines to deliver humanitarian assistance. 
A monitoring mechanism will be established under the UN Secretary-General's authority to verify humanitarian relief consignments. 
The mechanism will be deployed expeditiously. 
These decisions will expire 180 days from adoption and are subject to review. 
All Syrian parties must enable immediate and unhindered delivery of humanitarian assistance. 
The Council notes ceasefire agreements and humanitarian pauses could facilitate humanitarian assistance. 
It stresses the need to ensure the safety and security of UN and associated personnel. 
The only sustainable solution is an inclusive and Syrian-led political process. 
The Secretary-General is requested to report on implementation and compliance. 
The Council affirms it will take further measures in case of non-compliance and remains actively seized of the matter.
